description.narrative: The mission of the Astana CS Hub is to assist the governments of participating countries to enhance the civil service effectiveness

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1.New knowledge on civil service development is delivered to the Hub participating countries 2.Civil servants of the Hub participating countries are capacitated by ACSH to support civil service modernization efforts 3.South-South/East-East and Triangular Cooperation exchanges among Hub participating countries is facilitated

comment.narrative: 1.Lack of access to evidence-based knowledge on civil service development 2.Demand for building the capacity of national and local governments to implement development initiatives in an inclusive and participatory manner 3.Fragmented manner of Civil Service cooperation among the Hub participating countries

1. The regional and international role of the Astana Civil Service Hub is expanded as a globally recognized platform for exchange of knowledge, best practices and innovations in civil service reform, as well as in public service delivery. 2. The civil service institutions and participating countries are empowered and supported through building institutional and human capacity in civil service, thematic researches and comparative analysis, as well as by piloting and introducing innovative approaches and modern solutions in governance, including digitalization. 3. Extension of the ACSH beyond 2020 is successfully negotiated with GOK securing suitability and funding for the next phase.

1. Growing demand for the ACSH’s initiatives is evident by the increasing number of its participating countries rising from 25 to 42 and its institutional partners expanding from 5 to 80 in the past seven years. In 2020 the ACSH has signed three Memorandums of Understanding, bilateral – with Federal Public Service Policy and Support of the Kingdom of Belgium and the Hamad Bin Khalifa University (Qatar), trilateral – with the Agency of the Republic of Kazakhstan for Civil Service Affairs and HR Association of Kazakhstan, as well as and Exchange Letter of Cooperation on the South-South Network for Public Service Innovation launched by the Government of Bangladesh and the UN Office for South-South Cooperation; On 5 March 2020, during the ACSH delegation’s visit to Brussels, bilateral meetings were held- jointly UNDP Brussels Representation Office and the Embassy of Kazakhstan - with the Division for Central Asia, European External Action Service (EEAS) and the European Commission Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development (DG DEVCO). Both meeting counterparts were very much impressed by the activities and achievements of the ACSH and thus expressed their interest to work closely in the field of governance focusing on Central Asia, including Afghanistan. It was agreed to identify the needs of target countries and design a proposal within the New EU strategy for Central Asia (2021-2027); In 2020, partnership with OECD - one of the strategic partners and founders of the ACSH -enhanced further and reached new level; Considering special conditions in 2020 caused by the recent pandemic, ACSH has actively maintained partnership relations with all participating countries, international and national organizations, institutional partners, and other interested parties. Successful cooperation continued and strengthened in particular with representatives from Republic of Azerbaijan, Republic of Belarus, Belgium, Estonia, Georgia, Germany, Republic of Korea, Kyrgyz Republic, Republic of Uzbekistan and Ukraine and with such institutional partners as Association of HR Managers of Kazakhstan, Whiteshield Partners, Nazarbayev University, IIAS and AAPA. The countries and institutional partners have actively participated in activities initiated by the ACSH, conducted joint events and expressed readiness to enhance collaboration in civil service development; The ACSH continued its strategic collaboration with its key national partners, specialized agencies of the participating countries, professional organizations and associations, public administration educational institutions, etc., by initiating and implementing a wide range of activities with them. Their positive feedback demonstrates that the ACSH’s initiatives remain in high demand. Furthermore, the ACSH is continually exploring other sustainability opportunities by expanding its partnerships and networks with other international and regional organizations, and with potential donors. The ACSH received an endorsement for funding from the Republic of Korea to jointly implement a project on innovation in public administration and provision of digital public services through differentiated channels of delivery (2021-2023). 2. COVID-19 outbreak has forced governments to urgently adapt and properly respond to the pandemic.The crisis demonstrated that governments can be agile and adaptive. In this context, the ACSH organized a series events focused on discussion of the latest developments and crisis-induced challenges, including sharing experiences, achievements, lessons learnt, effective and innovative tools in order to contribute to global exchange of practical experiences and knowledge, and enhance further ways of cooperation, including peer to peer learning schemes. Overall, the ACSH conducted up to 30 partnership, capacity building, research, and knowledge management activities in 2020. In total, 3617 civil servants, scholars, and experts from 46 countries, including 2642 participants from Kazakhstan (men 1534 = 42 % and women 2083 = 58 %) benefitted from the ACSH’s partnership, capacity building, research initiatives focused on topics as HRM, digitalization, e-governance, telecommuting, crisis communications etc.; ACSH has launched the Virtual Alliance of practitioners for experience sharing in the context of Covid-19. The digital platform gathers and disseminates existing practices and innovative solutions employed in different countries. Several practical cases studies were provided by the peers, which later were disseminated through ACSH’s channels to all participating countries, including local state bodies. To date, over 10 countries and 20 organizations have contributed to this digital platform, disseminating over 40 cases and articles on existing practices and innovative solutions employed in the region and beyond. For example, the work of the alliance has supported the city of Turkestan in launching an easy-to-use system of online registration of entry, exit and movement of citizens during the COVID-19 lockdown. 3. In close partnership with the UNDP CO and respective bodies of the Government of Kazakhstan, ACSH kept working on further extension and advancement of the current initiatives. As a result, a proposal of the UNDP CO on extending the ACSH initiative for another 3 years, together with the allocation of additional funds in the order of USD 1.2 million annually has received endorsement and the relevant approval processes are ongoing. In order to enable the ACSH to honor its on-going commitments and to implement its outstanding activities uninterruptedly, while the approval process for the new phase is being finalized, the UNDP proposed to the Agency – in its capacity as the Implementing Partner – a twelve-month no-cost extension of the current Project. Such extension was formalized by exchange of letters between UNDP and the Agency.

1. The ACSH initiative has been extended beyond 2020 and the relavent agreement on fincning is signed between GOK and UNDP securing sustainability and funding for the next phase of the project 2021-2023 in amount of USD 3, 600, 000. The ACSH new phase (3) under Project ID 00123513 has been launched in November 2021. 2. The ACSH has continued expanding its network as a globally recognized platform for exchange of knowledge, best practices and innovations. For examples, the Government of the Republic of Korea has allocated $ 994,000 to UNDP and Astana Civil Service Hub to implement a regional project on Innovation and Digitalization in Governance in the countries of Central Asia and the Caucasus. For this purposes, in July 2021, an Agreement was signed between UNDP and the Ministry of the Interior and Safety of the Republic of Korea. The Project is designed for three years (2021-2023) and will be implemented utilizing the capacity of the Astana Civil Service Hub as a multilateral knowledge sharing platform. In the framework of the project, it is envisioned to conduct analytical studies, workshops and seminars to upgrade the skills of civil servants with involvement of leading Korean experts, as well as to organize study visits to government agencies of the Republic of Korea. 3. The Public Service Innovations Accelerator Lab was lauched as a joint initiative of the Astana Civil Service Hub, UNDP and Zerde National Infocommunication Holding JSC. The goal is to create conditions for the support and development of innovations in the field of public services in Kazakhstan. The lab is a platform for finding innovative solutions, approaches and technologies and for their incubations, accelerating and piloting in the relevant state body/institution of the Republic of Kazakhstan. The proposed lab seeks to contribute to the transformation of the public administration system of Kazakhstan taking full advantage of digital technologies, the acceleration and introduction of digital solutions nationwide, as well as digitalisation of civil service operations and processes to make it more resilient and capable of coping in crises situations well.

1. The role of the Astana Civil Service Hub expanded and capitalized on its success as a globally recognized platform for regional cooperation and partnership both domestically and internationally to better exchange knowledge and best practices in civil service reform among Kazakhstan and other countries in the region. 2. The civil service institutions and participating countries are empowered through exchange of knowledge, innovations in research, capacity building activities, expert networking drawn from the Astana Civil Service Hub and benefited from peer-to-peer learning, South-South / East-East and Triangular partnership mechanisms to apply and adapt best practices in civil service excellence.
